Rationality of Dedekind-Zeta Values

  • 1 Introduction
    • 1.1 Dedekind–Zeta function
    • 1.2 Motivating questions
    • 1.3 Rationality
  • 2 Plan for the study group

1 Introduction

1.1 Dedekind–Zeta function

Let \(\mathrm{K}\) be a totally real number field. Let \(\mathfrak{a}\) be an ideal inside the ring of integers \(\mathrm{O}_\mathrm{K}\). Consider the Dedekind-Zeta function:

\[\zeta_K(s) = \sum \limits_{\mathfrak{b}} \frac{1}{\mathrm{Norm}(\mathfrak{b})^s},\] along with the associated partial Dedekind–Zeta functions: \[\zeta_K(\mathfrak{a},s) = \sum \limits_{\mathfrak{b} \sim \mathfrak{a}} \frac{1}{\mathrm{Norm}(\mathfrak{b})^s},\] The first sum is taken with respect to all the integral ideals \(\mathfrak{b}\) in \(\mathrm{O}_\mathrm{K}\). The second sum is taken with respect to all the integral ideals \(\mathfrak{b}\) that are in the same class as \(\mathfrak{a}\) in the narrow ray class group of \(\mathrm{K}\).

1.2 Motivating questions

Here’s an overarching and sequential list of motivating questions:

  • (analytic continuation) Do the zeta functions \(\zeta_K(s)\) and \(\zeta_K(\mathfrak{a},s)\) have an analytic (or meromorphic) continuation to the entire complex plane?

  • (rationality) Having established analytic continuation, can we conclude that the zeta values at non-positive integers are rational?

  • (integrality) Having established rationality, for what primes \(p\) are these zeta-values \(p\)-integral?

  • (Kummer congruences) Having established \(p\)-integrality, how do we construct \(p\)-adic \(L\)-functions associated to these zeta values?

1.3 Rationality

The main motivating question for our study group for this semester will be the question of rationality of these zeta values. This is known as the Siegel–Klingen rationality theorem. There are three celebrated proofs of this result, attributed to:

  1. Siegel–Klingen (constant terms of Eisenstein series),

  2. Shintani, and

  3. Sczech (cohomological).

Our goal will be to read the methods of Shintani and Sczech. As a reminder to our eventual goal of studying \(p\)-adic \(L\)-functions, it is worth noting that in this set up, the constructions of the \(p\)-adic \(L\)-functions by

  1. Deligne–Ribet (Deligne and Ribet 1980),

  2. Cassou–Noguès (Cassou-Noguès 1978, 1979), and

  3. Charollois–Dasgupta (Charollois and Dasgupta 2014).

rely on the methods of Siegel–Klingen, Shintani and Sczech respectively.

\[\text{Siegel--Klingen} \rightarrowtail \text{Deligne--Ribet}\] \[\text{Shintani} \rightarrowtail \text{Cassou--Nogu\`es}\] \[\text{Sczech} \rightarrowtail \text{Charollois--Dasguptas}\]

References for Shintani’s method

  1. Shintani’s article (Shintani 1976)

  2. Hida’s book (Hida 1993)

References for Sczech’s method

  1. Sczech’s inventiones article (Sczech 1993).

  2. Sczech’s Kyushu article (Sczech 1996).

2 Plan for the study group

The study group will meet on Tuesdays, 10:30 am.

25 Jan Bharath Theorem 1 in (Shintani 1976) \(\implies\) Siegel–Klingen rationality Pages 393-394, 404
1 Feb Shaunak Proposition 1 and Corollary to Proposition 1 in (Shintani 1976) Pages 396-398

15 Feb Mihir Lemma 3 and Proposition 4 in (Shintani 1976) Pages 400-402
22 Feb Mahesh Proposition 4 and Theorem 1 in (Shintani 1976) Pages 402-404
Cassou-Noguès, Pierrette. 1978. “\(p\)-Adic \(L\)-Functions for Totally Real Number Field.” In Proceedings of the Conference on \(p\)-Adic Analysis (Nijmegen, 1978), 7806:24–37. Report. Katholieke Univ., Nijmegen.
———. 1979. “Valeurs Aux Entiers Négatifs Des Fonctions Zêta Et Fonctions Zêta \(p\)-Adiques.” Invent. Math. 51 (1): 29–59.
Charollois, Pierre, and Samit Dasgupta. 2014. “Integral Eisenstein Cocycles on \({\bf GL}_n\), I: Sczech’s Cocycle and \(p\)-Adic \(L\)-Functions of Totally Real Fields.” Camb. J. Math. 2 (1): 49–90.
Deligne, Pierre, and Kenneth A. Ribet. 1980. “Values of Abelian \(L\)-Functions at Negative Integers over Totally Real Fields.” Invent. Math. 59 (3): 227–86.
Hida, Haruzo. 1993. Elementary Theory of \(L\)-Functions and Eisenstein Series. Vol. 26. London Mathematical Society Student Texts. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge.
Sczech, Robert. 1993. “Eisenstein Group Cocycles for \({\rm GL}_n\) and Values of \(L\)-Functions.” Invent. Math. 113 (3): 581–616.
———. 1996. “Eisenstein Cocycles for Arithmetic Groups and Values of Zeta Functions.” In, 46–48. 958.
Shintani, Takuro. 1976. “On Evaluation of Zeta Functions of Totally Real Algebraic Number Fields at Non-Positive Integers.” J. Fac. Sci. Univ. Tokyo Sect. IA Math. 23 (2): 393–417.
